messages: 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:30): Where does it say that an SVG object should, by default, be scaled up to the maximum size that fits in its container?  Chrome seems to not be doing this.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:47): 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32, it doesn't say that anywhere.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:47): If it has an intrinsic size, it should be displayed like that.  If not, there's some default, like 300x150 px or something IIRC.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:48): Do you have a specific test case that different browsers display differently?
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (21:59): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Yes, the graphs on this page:  http://www.chaosreigns.com/dnswl/
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:00): Firefox displays them the full width of the page, as I want.  Chrome displays them tiny.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:01): I'm not an expert on this, but it looks to me that Chrome is right.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:01): 300x150 since there's no size specified.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:01): I don't know what's wrong with Firefox.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:02): Setting width:100% doesn't seem to make Chrome actually do that, though.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:02): So it seems to be buggy too.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:02): Not totally sure here.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:03): Chrome only displays it right if you give explicit height and width, it looks like.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:03): Dunno why.  Does it not have an intrinsic aspect ratio either?
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (22:03): 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32: what do you use to call the SVG? object element or something else.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:04): Chrome seems very buggy.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:04): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167, object in this case, see link.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:04): In fact, Chrome just gave me a sad tab.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:04): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167: Currently object.
6af7ad12dbeea3cf8f9c844826da40b3 (22:05): try giving the svg a fixed h/w
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (22:05): I have not checked what html5 was saying about object. HTML4/XHTML 1.0 was not always clear http://www.w3.org/QA/2004/02/object/object-test-case
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:06): This is handled by CSS.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:06): The .svg file starts with '<svg viewBox="0 0 1024 768"', so there is an aspect ratio defined.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:07): Oh that's interesting.  I just specified 'width="800"' and then Chrome moved the location of the image, keeping it small, and then crashed.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:07): I.. expected that to work.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:08): I think it centered the thumbnail in the 800 pixel width.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:08): Yeah, Chrome is crazy here.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:08): Dunno what it's smoking.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:08): So... I don't even know what the appropriate behavior is to report a bug...
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:08): What way(s) should I be able to tell chrome to make the .svg the width of its container?
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:09): I also tried specifying a width of 100% as a css property of object.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:10): It looks like nothing supports specifying an objects width as a percentage as an attribute of the entity?
6af7ad12dbeea3cf8f9c844826da40b3 (22:10): do you have firebug installed ?
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (22:11): http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/the-iframe-element.html#the-object-element
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:11): 6af7ad12dbeea3cf8f9c844826da40b3: No.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:11): <object style="width: 100%"> should work correctly AFAIK, but seems not to in Chrome.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:12): Thanks.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:13): Have you tried using <img>?

1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (22:13): >The two attributes must be omitted if the resource in question does not have both an intrinsic width and an intrinsic height. -- http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/the-map-element.html#attr-dim-width
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:13): That won't work in Firefox < 4, though.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:13): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Yes, one of them (firefox?) won't load a .svg as an <img>.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:13): Only Firefox, and only < 4.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:13): (plus ancient versions of other browsers, I guess)
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (22:13): it doesn't make sense. Or I'm not parsing the sentence correctly
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:14): Firefox < 4 is the version in the only release of Ubuntu that has been out more than a few weeks.  Seems worth supporting.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:14): "If 'height' and 'width' both have computed values of 'auto' and the element has an intrinsic ratio but no intrinsic height or width and the containing block's width does not itself depend on the replaced element's width, then the used value of 'width' is calculated from the constraint equation used for block-level, non-replaced elements in normal flow." http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/visudet.html#inline-replaced-width
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:14): Hmm, what does that mean?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:14): Maybe Firefox is right.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:14): 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32, yeah, Firefox 4 is still beta.
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (22:15): width and height must be omitted if the resource itself doesn't size values‚Ä¶ then there is no value defined anywhere. I must be missing something
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:15): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167, correct, then there's no value defined anywhere.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:15): width and height in HTML are only hints so that the UA knows the size before it loads the resource.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:15): Well, it's nice to know .svg will be supported as an <img> soon.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:15): http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/visudet.html#blockwidth
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:15): Okay, it looks like Firefox is correct here.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:15): I should have guessed.  :P
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:16): It looks like with an explicit ratio but no explicit height/width, it should just fill the width of the containing block.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:16): Not sure about "the containing block's width does not itself depend on the replaced element's width".
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:17): I guess it doesn't in this case.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:17): Anyway, Chrome is obviously braindead here, either way.

1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (22:17): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: but in the case of SVG would not that be precisely helpful to rely on width and height in the markup if there is no intrinsic size (defined).
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:17): Any of you more familiar with the details than me want to file the bug?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:17): 1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167, no, you should use CSS then.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:18): 3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32, I think you can file bugs against Chrome pointing out their obviously crazy behavior for <object style="width:100%">, and pointing out the crash.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:18): Although probably both are actually WebKit bugs.
3dc0456e027e36cfd9e180b0fb4e5f32 (22:18): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Sure, and I will if you guys don't, I'm just thinking one of you might manage a more useful report.
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (22:19): I guess if people can tweak width and height then the CMS will not remove the style attribute.
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (22:20): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: I imagine a case where people use CMS to edit content and having sanitization filters in place.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:21): What does that have to do with what we were talking about?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:21): Oh, a CMS that allows width/height but not style?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:21): Possible, yeah.

1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (22:21): trying to find out if there would be case where people could only edit width and height attribute on the markup and no access to the style attribute. But that seems to be unlikely
